H0.text: Mercury goes around the Sun every 88 days describes rotation.

H1.text: The Moon going around Earth every 28 days is a description of rotation.

H2.text: Earth orbits the Sun about every 365 days describes rotation.

H3.text: Earth makes one turn on its axis every 24 hours, which describes rotation.

A4.text: In the International System of Quantities (ISQ), rotation (symbol N) is a physical quantity defined as number of revolutions, for example, of a rotating body about a given axis.

A5.text: The turn (symbol tr or pla) is a unit of plane angle measurement that is the measure of a complete angleâ€”the angle subtended by a complete circle at its center.

A6.text: The speed at any given latitude can be calculated by multiplying the equatorial speed by the cosine of the latitude: at the equator, the speed is about 1,670 kilometres per hour (1,040 mph), calculated by dividing the Earth's equatorial circumference (approximately 40,075 kilometres (24,901 mi)) by the length of a sidereal day (approximately 23.93 hours).
